No other light my heart enthrones,

Thy mercy leads me on my race.  

Though shadows fall and tempests groan,  
I cling to Thee, my hiding place.  
O God! Thou art my God alone;  
In every breath, I sense Thy trace.

Breath when sheathed by the web of ebbs—
A gentle yielding to the pull of tides,
Where every exhale lingers, softly pressed
By moonlit currents, woven, undenied.
The hush of water, delicate and vast,
Wraps round the chest and cradles weary bones;
Here, in the hush, the world drifts slow and past,
And memory dissolves in undertones.
Suspended in the net of what recedes,
We find the strength to wait, to simply be—
To gather hope from what the silence breeds,
And let the breath return, unbound and free.
For in the ebb, the heart learns how to rest,
And trust the tide will bring back what is best.

How strangely sweet, how oddly still,
The hours now when I have a cold.

That's my window. This minute
Catches the blush of dawn,
A canvas brushed with possibility,
Where old regrets are gone.

The glass is cool beneath my hand,
Mist gathering at the edge,
And all the dreams I’ve ever had
Flutter against the ledge.

Outside, the city murmurs on,
But here, I’m held in light—
That's my window. This minute,
And everything feels right.
